bestBHT.bht: This provides insight into the fidelity of John the Baptist towards his royal hearer, Herod. Despite his recognition of Herod's enslavement to passion and the multitude of evil deeds committed, John fearlessly reproved him. John's courageous moral stance, not hesitating to confront the wrath of the powerful, serves as an exemplar for all pious teachers. It is a reminder of the challenges faced by faithful ministers who reprove vices, often met with hostility, making John's willingness to bear the consequences praiseworthy.

Marvin Vincent: Evils [πονηρων] . Of several words in the New Testament denoting evil, this emphasizes evil in its activity. Hence Satan is oJ ponhrov, the evil one."
An evil eye (Mark 7:22) is a mischief working eye.
Added [προσεθηκεν] . Used by Luke twice as often as in all the rest of the New Testament. A very common medical word, used of the application of remedies to the body, as our apply, administer.
John Calvin: This history shows clearly, what sort of reward awaits the faithful and honest ministers of the truth, particularly when they reprove vices: for scarcely one in a hundred bears reproof, and if it is at all severe, they break out into fury."

We behold in John an illustrious example of that moral courage, which all pious teachers ought to possess, not to hesitate to incur the wrath of the great and powerful, as often as it may be found necessary: for he, with whom there is acceptance of persons, does not honestly serve God.

Herod’s malice is become desperate, and has reached its utmost height, when the sinner is enraged by remedies, and not only refuses correction, but takes vengeance on his adviser, as if he had been his enemy.
Philip Schaff: This took place afterwards. It is inserted here to complete the sketch of John’s ministry."
All the evil things which Herod had done. See Mark 6:17-20, where Herod’s willingness to hear him is brought out.
Archibald T. Robertson: The word is from πονοσ, πονεω, toil, work, and gives the active side of evil, possibly with the notion of work itself as evil or at least an annoyance."
The 'evil eye' (οφθαλμος πονηρος in Mark 7:22) was a 'mischief working eye' (Vincent).
It is a very common adjective in the N.T. as in the older Greek.
John Gill: Herod Antipater, and there are some that call him, טיטרקי "the tetrarch", was a son of Herod the first, and brother of Archelaus'; and he was the third king of the family of Herod; and he was very wicked, and a destroying man...
And John reproved him not only for this sin, but others: and for all the evils which Herod had done; his revellings, debaucheries, murders, &c.
For Herod had had a particular respect for him, and often had him with him, and heard him gladly, when John had an opportunity of speaking personally to him.

bhtAttempts.bht: It is emphasized that Herod in Luke 3:19 was not only someone who had done evil things in general, but also someone who had done many evil things (πονηρων) actively and continuously. The phrase the evil one (οJ πονηρος) is associated with Satan and highlights the active and working nature of evil. The mention of an evil eye in Mark 7:22 reinforces this idea of an eye that brings harm or mischief. Herod's response to John the Baptist's reproof demonstrates how rare it is for someone to accept and bear reproof, particularly when it is severe. Nevertheless, John displayed moral courage by fearlessly reproving the powerful, even if it meant incurring their wrath. Herod's reaction is a reflection of the extreme malice and desperation of a sinner who refuses correction and seeks vengeance on his adviser. Overall, this passage serves as a reminder of the importance of faithful ministers of truth who are willing to confront and reprove evil, regardless of the potential consequences.

This verse sheds light on the thorough fidelity of John the Baptist towards Herod, despite having a deep understanding of his sinful actions. It is significant that Herod, a slave to his passions, willingly heard John's message and added it to his life like applying a remedy. The mention of evil things emphasizes the active nature of evil, often manifested through mischief or harm. John's reproof to Herod shows moral courage, highlighting the need for honest ministers unafraid to confront vices, even if facing the wrath of the powerful.
